MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - GATT/CAP Implications.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture and Food if his attention has been drawn to the implications of the current round of GATT negotiations for the Common Agricultural Policy; and the proposals, if any, he has for the implementation of the Punta Del Este declaration.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. O'Kennedy) Michael O'Kennedy
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. O'Kennedy)
Speaker.P: The current round of GATT negotiations covers international trade relations in all sectors including agriculture. The aim in relation to agriculture, as set out in the Punta Del Este Declaration of September 1986, is the greater liberalisation of agricultural trade through the improvement of market access and the introduction of increased disciplines on the use of all subsidies. These objectives were reaffirmed at the mid-term review in April of this year when contracting parties agreed to the long term aim of substantially reducing support and protection levels and of ensuring that agricultural policies are made more responsive to market signals. Notwithstanding this agreement some contracting parties are pressing for the full liberalisation of agriculture trade including the abolition of all trade subsidies.

The Deputy can be assured that I am in close touch with all the developments in the GATT Uruguay Round. The Community's attitude, which I endorse, is that while the EC are willing to participate in negotiations leading to greater freedom of trade the fundamental principles of CAP are not negotiable. My principal aims are to ensure that the Community gets credit for past reforms, that there are balanced commitments from all parties, and that the Community can continue to support farming and rural areas generally. It is much too early to predict the outcome of the GATT negotiations but it is certain that new disciplines and constraints on agricultural supports will result.

Nevertheless, I believe that the final agreement will ensure greater price and supply stability on international markets, thus allowing our producers and traders to exploit the opportunities available to them in a more liberalised and stable trading system.

MainHeading.P: The Commission is presently preparing a substantive paper on its long term approach to the negotiations. At the request of a number of Ministers, including myself, the Council of Agricultural Minister is expected to discuss the agricultural aspects of the paper on the 11/12 December. I will, of course, be expressing the views outlined above and will endeavour to ensure that our interests are safeguarded.

Speaker.P: Under the provisions of the equal treatment legislation, a spouse is allowed to earn up to £50 gross per week without affecting the adult dependancy status on a claim to disability benefit. Speaker.P: There are no funds devoted to Motor Neurone disease specifically. Persons suffering from the disease are eligible for the general range of services which health boards provide. Health boards may make arrangements for the provision of home nursing care for patients suffering from this disease when required. Such persons may also qualify for disabled persons maintenance allowance and home help service. Special aids are provided free of charge to those who are medical card holders. Non-medical card holders are not entitled to special aids free of charge but health boards may make them available to patients having regard to their individual circumstances.
When hospice care is required arrangements may be made by the general practitioner or consultant to refer them for assessment to the appropriate local hospice.

An application from the Irish Motor Neurone Disease Association for funding from the health allocation of the national lottery proceeds has been received by my Department. This application has been noted for consideration in the context of the lottery funds available for health services for the remainder of this year. When a final decision is reached it will be communicated to the association.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Sligo School Bus Service.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if her attention has been drawn to the unsatisfactory nature of the bus service provided to take mentally handicapped children from the south Sligo area to special schools and other training facilities; to the fact that one bus has been recently withdrawn; that, as a result, some of the children have to spend a total of four hours a day as their bus covers its circuitous route, morning and evening and as a result their training and general education is suffering; whether it is unreasonable of her Department to ask a driver of a bus to supervise on his own, 18 mentally handicapped students in addition to the demanding job of driving the bus; and if she will review the position of the withdrawal of the bus and immediately add another bus.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: Special national schools have, unavoidably, lengthy school transport journeys due to the geographical dispersion of relatively small numbers of pupils over large areas; this is reflected in this case in that some of the pupils are 25 to 30 miles from the special schools.

The reorganisation of the transport service to these schools was caused by a reduction in the number of pupils to be catered for and did not result in significant increases in journey times for pupils. The longest journey time involved is one hour thirty five minutes, but this pupil lives 30 miles from the special school.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Education Grants.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if, in view of the fact that qualifying third level students obtain a grant of £1,200 if they live 15 miles or more away from the third level institution and only £500 if they are below 15 miles, she will consider the introduction of a graded system through which those marginally below the 15 mile limit would qualify for a higher grant and thus remove the major anomaly in the system which exists at present.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The lower (adjacent) and higher (non-adjacent) rates of maintenance payable under the higher education grants scheme are £525 and £1,318 respectively. Full lecture fee is also payable in each case in addition to these amounts.

MainHeading.P: The lower rate of maintenance is payable in the case of a candidate whose normal family residence is within 15 miles of the university or other institution of higher education at which he/she is attending or who could reasonably be expected, in the light of distance and local public transport services, to travel daily between his/her normal family residence and such university or other institution of higher education. The higher rate of maintenance is payable in other cases.
I have no plans at the moment to modify the higher education grants scheme which regulates the circumstances in which the lower and higher rates of maintenance may be paid to an eligible student.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will outline her response to the request of a school (details supplied) in Dublin 1 for the additional teacher; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The staffing of this school for the 1989-90 school year has been determined in accordance with the agreement between the Government and the INTO under the Programme for National Recovery.
Under these arrangements the appointment of an additional teacher in the school cannot be sanctioned in the current school year.

In addition to the normal staffing complement, the school benefits from a concessionary teaching post allocated under the special scheme for schools serving disadvantaged areas, and also has a full-time remedial teacher on the staff.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Kerry Recreational Club Funding.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will make a grant available to Castleisland Pitch and Putt Club, County Kerry under the recreational grant scheme administered by her Department.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: No funds are available to my Department from which consideration could be given to grant-aiding the Castleisland Pitch and Putt Club County Kerry.

MainHeading.P: Such applications will now fall to be considered under the new arrangements for the capital grants/amenity grants scheme referred to by the Minister for Finance in his reply of 24 October 1989 to Questions Nos. 26, 48 and 55.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Navan, Meath, School Transport.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will increase the number of school transport buses collecting children who are attending St. Mary's Special School, Athlumney, Navan, County Meath whose ages range from four years to 18 years having regard to the fact that at present some of these children have to leave home at 7.30 a.m. to arrive in school at 9.30 a.m.; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: Special national schools have, unavoidably, lengthy school transport journeys due to the geographical dispersion of relatively small numbers of pupils over large areas.
The standard of service available to the pupils is similar to the standard of service on offer to pupils attending similar educational facilities throughout the country.
Ten buses are now being used to transport pupils to the two special schools in Navan (St. Mary's and St. Ultan's).

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Galway New Primary School.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education when work will commence on the proposed new primary school at Clonbur, County Galway as the old school is in a very bad state of repair.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I accept that conditions at Clonbur National School, County Galway are unsatisfactory. The question of the improvement and updating of the school building is being considered in the context of the available capital. A decision will be conveyed to the school authorities at the earliest possible date. I am not in a position, at this stage, to say when building works might commence.
